ANTLR:
```
grammar Interactive;

@parser::header {
    import java.io.BufferedReader;
    import java.io.InputStreamReader;
}

@parser::members {
    {
        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
        TokenStream ts = new ANTLRInputStream(br);
        Interactive exprParser = new Interactive(ts);
    }
}

parse : (line EOF)+ ;

line : command NEWLINE
     | NEWLINE
     ;

command : ID '=' expr
        | expr
        ;

expr : ID
     | INT
     | '(' expr ')'
     | expr ('*'|'/') expr
     | expr ('+'|'-') expr
     ;

ID : [a-zA-Z]+ ;
INT : [0-9]+ ;
NEWLINE : '\r'? '\n' ;
WS : [ \t]+ -> skip ;
```

<<<explanation>>>: This ANTLR grammar can be used to parse interactive commands. The parser reads from System.in using ANTLRInputStream and BufferedReader. The grammar defines a parse rule that matches one or more lines. A line can be either a command or a newline. A command can be an assignment (ID '=' expr) or just an expression. The expression can be an ID, an INT, a parenthesized expression, or an expression with '*' or '/', followed by an expression with '+' or '-'. The grammar also defines ID and INT lexer rules to match identifiers and integers, and NEWLINE to match newlines. The WS rule is used to skip whitespace.

This grammar can be used to parse interactive commands in a loop, for example:

```java
while (true) {
    Interactive exprParser = new Interactive(new ANTLRInputStream(br));
    exprParser.parse();
    // do something with the result
}
```

This will continuously read commands from System.in and parse them, without re-parsing the same commands. However, it will re-parse all commands each time, which can be slow if the commands are complex. To avoid this, you could keep track of the last parsed command and only re-parse it if it has changed.
